body:
This project will focus on redesigning Photoshops UI for the visually impaired.


Photoshop is ubiquitous in the design world. It is so widely used that it’s name has become synonymous with photo editing to the point that it has become a verb. It’s robust toolset has been developed over the past 30 years and is universally accepted as the final word in image manipulation software. However, alternatives still manage to survive.


There are long standing major obstacles in the way of users that wish to use Photoshop. An appraisal of user reviews online can identify several. The biggest problem with Photoshop for users is the steep learning curve with it’s cumbersome UI featuring regularly in user issues as well.
title: Text Title

body: The following are the inclusive design principles being taken into consideration for this project.
title: Inclusive Design Principles Intro

body: Low vision principles retrieved from: https://ukhomeoffice.github.io/accessibility-posters/lowvision
displayTitle: Designing for users with low vision
title: Designing for users with low vision

body: Astigmatism is a condition that causes blurred vision that cannot be fully corrected with optometry. Astigmatism is the blurring of vision caused by misshapen cornea or lenses in the eye. The defect causes light to be unevenly distributed across the retina in an asymmetric fashion that lenses cannot fully correct. Roughly 30% of the world's population is affected by astigmatism. Even a slight astigmatism can cause eyestrain and headaches.
title: Text Title

body: A user test of the target audience provided a baseline blur level that could be used to test the design. At the recommended 52cm distance from a monitor, the text became illegible between 25px and 30px in height.
title: User Test Vision

_items.body: Photoshop, on a 1080p screen with Photoshop UI settings at maximum and computer UI set to 150%.
Photoshop, on a 1080p screen with Photoshop UI settings at maximum and computer UI set to 150%. As perceived from someone with severe astigmatism at 52cm distance sitting upright.

body: Click the arrows to the left and right of the screenshots to view the next/previous screenshot.
title: Narrative Title

body:
In 2017, Virgin Australia developed an in-flight user interface for the visually impaired.


This design follows many best practices for designing for visual impairment. It is in different values of the same colour with high contrast and it uses large interaction areas with well-defined shapes. However the text and iconography could be better optimized by swapping places to allow the icons to sit in the middle of the large circle to better utilize the space for visibility.


Click the arrows to the left and right of the screenshots to view the next/previous screenshot.
title: Narrative Title

body: In order to solve Photoshop's accessibility problems, increasing text size will not be enough. The number 1 issue found among users is the difficulty curve for the software. This impacts first time discoverability and ongoing re-discoverability of the software. The interface needs to become more pattern based and visual to address this. The reading below illustrates the importance of leveraging visual memory for recall.
title: Text Title

_items.title: Perception and memory for pictures: Single-trial learning of 2500 visual stimuli
_items.body:
This paper details a study in-which participants were shown 2560 images for ten seconds each. Following this, using a two-alternative forced-choice assessment, recall exceeded 90% indicating retention of over 2000 items even when up to 3 days elapsed between learning and testing.


This study demonstrates how inherently effective the brain is at retaining visual information.

The Virtual Memory Palace is an expansion on the ancient Greek memorization technique the "Memory Palace". In this paper, a virtual 3d architectural model was used to teach users information. Retention of the information provided in this way was significantly higher than with words alone.


This paper demonstrated the importance of context-specific information in the user's ability to recall information.
_items.title: The Virtual Memory Palace

_items.body:
Daniel Kahneman discusses the use of two systems in the human brain in his book Thinking Fast and Slow. These systems are system one and system two. System one is effortless like walking, system deals in effortful tasks. When you have to sit up and concentrate on a task that has proven to be more difficult than you expected, the discomfort you feel is your system two engaging with the process. The sentiment in this book is echoed in Steve Krug's book Don't Make Me Think.


The key point to be taken away from this book is that, wherever possible, ensure that your designs engage the user's system one as much as possible. Make it effortless.
_items.title: Thinking Fast and Slow

body: User research identified a difficulty in learning Photoshop and a cumbersome UI to be a primary issue with the software. With the small UI elements in Photoshop, these usability issues are compounded for the visually impaired.
title: Problem Statement - Blurb

body:
Interviews with two visually impaired creative professionals highlighted anxiety around their vision based work difficulties in the office.


Transcripts of these interviews can be found here:

Participant 1 interview

Participant 2 interview
title: Interviews - Blurb

body: The pain points to focus on here are all the moments the visually impaired creative is trying to get work done as quickly as possible. High focus causes high strain potential.

body: Competitor design software all shares a strong similarity to Photoshop. There is a frame around the active area in which they show the user as much tools as possible at once.
title: Text Title

body: This mood board focuses on circular UI. This moves away from the somewhat dated look of square windows sitting on top of active design canvases. Video games have utilized circular UIs for years, most recognizably in the weapon wheel that has been in use since the early 2000s.

body:
“The buttons are much easier to see, it's very clear from the symbols what is where.”


“In Photoshop it’s much harder to find what you need.”


“In the new program, I had to strain a lot less to find things. It was much faster.”


“Photoshop can do more advanced things. There are a lot more options in Photoshop but Photoshop is much more awkward.”
title: Text Title

body:
“I much prefer the second one”


“Adding a new layer was a lot easier on the second one. There was a lot going on in the first one.”


“This one seemed a lot more intuitive.”


“Having the options on the screen was nice.”


“In the second one you knew exactly where to go. It was easy to find it and it was very easy to remember it. Once you’ve done it once it was quick doing it a second time.”

“It clearly didn’t have the same capabilities of Photoshop though. If I wanted to get into all kinds of nitty gritty stuff I am sure I would want to learn how to use Photoshop.”

title: Narrative Title

body:
The goal of this project was to solve the problems experienced by visually impaired users while extending the solutions to the wider user base by alleviating discoverability and findability issues.


The intent of this project was to assess the viability of a plugin for Photoshop’s fullscreen mode that provides intuitive task-specific workspaces and allows users to use Photoshop more easily. Additionally, the UI elements devised for this prototype aimed to provide a more tablet-ready interface to align with Photoshops initiatives to accommodate tablet users.


The focus of this project was to explore options for making photoshop more accessible to the visually impaired. The scope of this project was narrowed to the tools required to do basic Photoshop painting tasks. One of the intended success metrics for this was to assess whether the prototype allowed visually impaired users to perform tasks without having to be as close to the screen as they do with Photoshop as it currently exists. This was not the case. A key factor in allowing visually impaired users to distance themselves from the screen is the mouse cursor which was not taken into consideration for this design.


When it comes to the task to making Photoshop more accessible to the visually impaired there are some basic accessibility features that can be added to the tool to make it more usable that this project did not have time to address. The current app does not give users much control over the UI and text size and the selection tool, a commonly used feature, is a single pixel thick. Adding in options for increasing the size of the text and selection indicators would alleviate visual strain.


Improvements to the design were witnessed in the ease of navigation and identification of the interactive elements. Based on the results of the user testing, the redesigned prototype proved to be easier to read and more intuitive than Photoshops current design. With this taken into account, the prototype can be considered a success.
title: Text Title

body: A small aspect of Photoshop was emulated and redesigned in this prototype. Moving forward an investigation of how this design can be expanded to allow users the full range of photoshop’s capabilities would be needed.
title: Text Title
